Chromium sink fixtures and a frosted-glass shower threw back cerulean light. In contrast to the other flooded chambers there was no mold, no algae, no water damage. It might have been flooded seconds before.

45451.base_text: I focused on my strokes, old swimming lessons coming back. This was a different sort of lane, of course: the floor brown carpet, plaster-of-paris above instead of a shimmering boundary of air. And the wounded leg slowed me down: it hurt, every time I kicked. But I wasn’t worried, not yet. I had good lungs. I could swim for a while.

45451.base_text: Through the door was what looked like a small porch or mud room. Boots and shoes tumbled weightless in the water. The rope stopped here, tied to a capped metal pipe. The opposite wall was a sliding glass patio door.

45451.base_text: The airlock.

Through the glass it was dark. All I could see was my own blue reflection holding the glowstick. Seeing myself floating there, a hit of adrenaline coursed through me. How much air was left in my lungs? More than half what I’d started with? Doubt flooded into me. This is crazy. I can’t do this. I forced the thought from my mind, replaced it with: Just hurry. Hurry and get it over with.

45451.base_text: Another me.

Everything changed. The water cooled; the pressure and ambient sound in my ears shifted. I could see the vague outlines of another sliding door just ahead of me, but it seemed too as if I floated in a cavernous space, a space beyond measuring, the other door impossibly distant. Disoriented, I turned around to shut the one I’d come through—remembering they couldn’t both be open at once—and as I did another shock of change swept through me, crystallizing into something immense, yawning, terrorful. I remembered the spring Elder Niko had spoken of

45451.base_text: The water trembled and around us foundations groaned, but I reached down and grabbed Niko’s hand and held it tight against the wriggling water, and he gripped it back. We stared across the gap at my double, defiant. I realized half the sick anxiety I’d been feeling was from my growing proximity to him, subsumed by the general terror of what we were doing. But that wasn’t why I gripped Niko’s hand so tight.

45451.base_text: EXPANDING ONCE AGAIN

Slowed by dream-syrup, fighting awed stupor from these whispers of immensity, I turned my back on that powerful water at the center, pulled the glass door shut, staring numb as it slid implacable down its track.

45451.base_text: SUCH WONDERS

They drifted in that immense and empty space, lit a gangrenous blue by the light of my glowstick. Three of them. All with my body, my clothes. My face. Their wide-open eyes (my eyes) were fixed on me as they floated gently forward, converging.

45451.base_text: I screamed, bubbles of precious oxygen exploding from my mouth. I yanked the handle of the door, but it wouldn’t budge. I clawed at it, slammed my fist against the glass. The darkness was absolute, thickened by the potent water into a solid, crushing thing. The door wouldn’t open and they were right behind me they were coming they were going to get me and I twisted wildly, pressed hands to the glass behind me, trying to guess their position, but it was hopeless. I couldn’t see. I’d squandered my air. Hands would close around my neck, my face, and I’d scream again one last time and drown, thrashing in pain and terror and darkness. Alone.

45451.base_text: No.

Anger pierced through fear. Maybe I had issues and maybe I’d made mistakes, and maybe I even deserved this, to be strangled by my own soulless doppelgangers in a shitty basement apartment with delusions of grandeur. But I didn’t want to die, and being alone had nothing to do with it. I wasn’t going to let this happen to me just because my first love had betrayed me and I couldn’t forgive him, just because my second was trapped in another universe and I could never, ever see him again. None of that mattered. I was still here. I was still alive.

Think.

variants.text: I screamed, bubbles of precious oxygen exploding from my mouth, and then they came for us.

45451.base_text: Something brushed my leg. I kicked forward, pulled water with cupped hands and all the strength I had. Two fingertips bounced off my forehead, trailed through my hair, but I was moving too fast for them, I was through, I was past them. I’d done it.

45451.base_text: I twisted around and yanked the handle of the door, but it wouldn’t budge. I clawed at it, slammed my fist against the glass. The door wouldn’t open and they were right behind they were coming they were going to get us and I twisted wildly, pressed hands to the glass behind me, but it was hopeless. There were too many of them, drifting forward with hands outstretched, serene expressions on their faces. Beside me, Niko was preparing to push off against the glass and make a break for the other side, but faltered as he saw what was happening across from us.

45451.base_text: I surged forward, swimming hard, a savage rictus of victory splitting my face, and then with a crunch and flash of pain I slammed face-first into something hard and smooth. Glass. The door on the opposite side.

45451.base_text: The other Ryan had failed to open his door, too, but as he’d turned around a coincidence had pried apart our synchronicity even further. There were more of the floating Ryan-things on his side—an accident of distribution maybe—and the few seconds Niko and I had to act had already run out for him. As he bent his legs to push off from the glass door, they reached him.

45451.base_text: Seeing stars, tasting blood, I scrabbled for the handle, but I couldn’t find it. My hands slid off smooth glass in every direction. I smeared them across it frantically, up, down, side to side, kicking out with my feet, conscious every second of those things behind me, turning, drifting back towards me, closing in; of the air in my lungs, running low. Running out.

45451.base_text: He screamed, eyes going wide as their fingers wrapped around his hair, caressed his arms, reached pale white fingers into his mouth. Bubbles of air exploded from it as he twisted frantically, trying to shake them off. Hands closed around his neck, twisted his arms, pulled his head back by his hair to a terrible angle; hands that seemed unsure if they meant to caress or kill. He was panicking, writhing in the water like a trapped eel, dying.

45451.base_text: There: the handle. I pulled it sideways, and as the door slid open in its groove my glowstick came back on, the most glorious shade of blue you could possibly imagine.

I’d escaped them. My face throbbed with a sharp, spreading pain. But I had a bigger problem. In fact with lightheaded desperation I realized I was in deep, deep shit.

My air was almost gone. I’d lost some panicking, and my muscles burned through the rest as I shot myself through the airlock. An urge to breathe was taking hold of me, a tingling thrum running through my body as cells clamored for air. My lungs were empty. I couldn’t swim again the distance I’d come, either forward or back.

45451.base_text: It’s a horrible thing to watch yourself drown. My brain disconnected, floated away, observed only in abstractions as the me across the gap spasmed and convulsed, surrounded by things that shared our face, pressing forward, closer, eager, like they wanted to feed off the flicker of his death. The guttering green of his thrashing glowstick was doubled, reflecting mirrored patterns in the glass behind him.

45451.base_text: I watched myself swim into the room, holding it.

45451.base_text: More of the Ryan-things were drifting toward us, Niko was yanking frantic at my arm, but I couldn’t move, couldn’t react, struggling to grasp that fleeting thought like a half-remembered dream. Neurons tried to spark. The doubled reflection. Something had almost slipped into place. Like a puzzle in that damn adventure game, a puzzle you don’t even know if there’s an answer to until the moment you see it.

This wasn’t one of the things, I realized. It was me. My double, from the other side.

45451.base_text: Blood diffused from my nose in billowing red clouds; the cut on my leg burned a deep, dangerous ache. My torn fingernails stung where I’d clawed at the door. I was damaged, flawed. The worse-off copy. Looking at him, unharmed, whole, I accepted that I was about to die. It was surprisingly easy.

45451.base_text: There was no way, no time to explain this to Niko. So I wrapped my arms around him tight, felt for the glass door with my legs, shut my eyes, and pushed off hard towards the swarm of encroaching Orions, as hard as I could.

45451.base_text: Do it, I thought, I’m too broken to make it. Go back. Or go forward. Just go. Live. Be the one who lives.

45451.base_text: And then he launched himself at me. At once the sense of wrongness spiked, as if approaching some exponential maxima. His face winced at this in exact sympathy with mine, but he didn’t pull up, slow down. Instead he crashed right into me, hard. Tumbling, he wrapped his arms around me, held me, did the last thing I’d have ever expected.

45451.base_text: We’d reached the glass door on the other side; below us, the drowned Orion sank into erasing darkness, no longer struggling. I couldn’t help him. But Niko was kicking and thrashing in what I’d assumed was terror at the illusory Mockups. To pull the door open I’d have to let him go. But as I did I realized the reason for his panic was far more serious.

45451.base_text: He was out of air.

The wrongness had reached an unbearable threshold. But as his lips touched mine the sensation exploded outward, like magnets pushed against repelling poles till they slip from your fingers, flip around, snap into place. The water quivered around us; the room groaned, launching wet clouds of mud from splintering lintels, sending subsonic shockwaves shuddering through us. His breath flowed into me. I couldn’t think, let alone protest or react. Boots tumbled around us, long laces waving like antennae. I remember that.

They were almost gone. His lungs were empty.

45451.base_text: A huge rumbling crack broke over the growing crescendo of rumbles and groans, and we both looked up. The ceiling had split in a long ugly scar. But the room wasn’t collapsing on us. The split filled in almost immediately with new plaster, just as a different split bisected it, which also instantly filled.

45451.base_text: The room was getting bigger.

I pulled back, and as I did the water exploded around us like it had come to life, gone in a snap from still to carbonated. All around us the architecture groaned, flexed, heaved, like it too had come alive.

variants.text: I pulled back, and as I did the water exploded around us like it had come to life, gone in a snap from still to carbonated. All around us the architecture groaned, flexed, heaved, like it too had come alive.

45451.base_text: My double grabbed my elbow, pushed me toward the hall he’d come in through, the way to the hatch to the other world, my world. And I started to swim. I shouldn’t have. I should have thanked him. I should have given back half his air, or dragged him after me, found some way to save him. I should have died. But I didn’t. I swam. I swam with everything I had left.

variants.text: My double grabbed my elbow, pushed me toward the hall he’d come in through, the way to the hatch to the other world, my world. And I started to swim. I shouldn’t have. I should have thanked him. I should have given back half his air, or dragged him after me, found some way to save him. I should have died. But I didn’t. I swam. I swam with everything I had left.

45451.base_text: Across the gap of thrumming water behind us I saw the glass door we’d come through pull back. Its dimensions and the reflection of my glowstick grew smaller.

variants.text: Across the gap of thrumming water behind us I saw the glass door we’d come through pull back. Its dimensions and the reflection of my glowstick grew smaller.

45451.base_text: He’d made a mistake. Bet on the wrong horse. But I wouldn’t forget it. I wouldn’t forget him.

variants.text: He’d made a mistake. Bet on the wrong horse. But I wouldn’t forget it. I wouldn’t forget him.

45451.base_text: The wall was pulling away.

All around me the architecture was groaning, flexing, like something waking up. Plaster dust pillowed into the flooded hall in thick weightless clouds as the walls split and reformed, split and reformed, like bones breaking and healing and rebreaking, growing fractionally longer each time. I swam past a crack that didn’t fill in but puckered into a new doorway, a flap of wallpaper lengthening and hardening into door. New doorways were spawning all around me; new pits gaped open in the floor. I ignored it all. I swam. I swam for my fucking life.

I swam past a crack that didn’t fill in but puckered into a new doorway, a flap of wallpaper lengthening and hardening into door. New doorways were spawning all around me; new pits gaped open in the floor. I ignored it all. I swam. I swam for my fucking life.

45451.base_text: Desperate, my own need to breathe becoming overwhelming, I faced forward again and tugged the glass door beside us open; but even as I did, Downstairs expanded. Plaster dust pillowed into the flooded hall in thick weightless clouds as the walls split and reformed, split and reformed, like bones breaking and healing and rebreaking, growing fractionally longer each time. New glass doors spawned above us, below us, to every side. I ignored it all. I pulled the door open along its rail and grabbed Niko’s arm to shove him through.

New glass doors spawned above us, below us, to every side. I ignored it all. I pulled the door open along its rail and grabbed Niko’s arm to shove him through.

45451.base_text: The guide rope, taut as a bowstring, snapped, whipping past my face as its two endpoints pulled away from each other. It didn’t matter. I knew the way.

variants.text: The guide rope, taut as a bowstring, snapped, whipping past my face as its two endpoints pulled away from each other. It didn’t matter. I knew the way.

45451.base_text: He gripped the edge as I did, twisting around to grasp my shoulder. There were no words for the look on his face, or for all the things we’d never said to each other and now never would. There was no time to say them and no air to say them with. I could guess what some of them would have been, maybe, but not others. There was so much of him I’d never really seen, never understood, too caught up in manufacturing other versions of him in my head to know the only one who’d really been there. Now I’d never know how much I’d missed.

45451.base_text: I swam into the mirror bathroom, shiny new sinks sprouting on the floor, on the ceiling; the toilet multiplying and splitting in porcelain osmosis, someone’s pretentious art project. I swam up to the ceiling—already much higher than a bathroom ceiling should be—put my hands on the wheel of the hatch, and turned.

45451.base_text: I pulled back gently from his grasping hand, and smiled, and tried to put everything left I wanted to say into that.

variants.text: I pulled back gently from his grasping hand, and smiled, and tried to put everything left I wanted to say into that.

45451.base_text: It didn’t budge.

Water frothed around us, twisting, expanding. And then in a flash it began to move. A current tore him from me, limbs flailing, pulling him backward through the mudroom and down the twin of the hall we’d swum through to get here, toward the other hatch. I hoped. Toward the right surface. Even if I’d wanted to follow, I couldn’t have: another current of shockingly cold water had wrapped itself around me like a tendril. An angry, biotic undertow pulled me down, straight down, with vicious force. The reflection of my glowstick strobed as the current pulled me past door after door of sliding glass, faster and faster: a flicker, then a dull throb, fading and mingling with the phantom patterns and flashes of color now dancing across my vision as my oxygen-starved brain began to shut down.

45451.base_text: The groaning rumbles of hell surrounded me, my body was once again starting to tingle as my second lungful of air reached its end, my face throbbed and my leg was on fire, and the wheel wouldn’t turn.

variants.text: The groaning rumbles of hell surrounded me, my body was once again starting to tingle as my second lungful of air reached its end, my face throbbed and my leg was on fire, and the wheel wouldn’t turn.

45451.base_text: In a moment I’d breathe in, and I wondered what it would be like to inhale those waters of possibility, let that multiplying spring inside me. Let it fill me up. I harbored no illusions, of course: I’d seen it happen to the other Ryan. I’d die. But a beautiful way to go, in the abstract at least. A life spent worrying about possibilities would end by drowning in them. Neat.

45451.base_text: I pounded on the hatch, screaming in fury, the sound utterly lost in the cacophonous eruption of architecture beneath me.

variants.text: I pounded on the hatch, screaming in fury, the sound utterly lost in the cacophonous eruption of architecture beneath me.

45451.base_text: This peaceful thought had so taken me I was caught utterly by surprise when the current shifted and smashed me into a pane of glass with so much force it shattered. Rocketing through a waterlogged hall of turbulent water, surrounded by tumbling fragments of glass, head throbbing and vision expiring, I opened my mouth in shock and, before I could remember I was waiting for a poetic moment to die, breathed in.

45451.base_text: I braced myself, gripped the wheel so hard I thought my knuckles would pop, pulled on it with everything I had.

variants.text: I braced myself, gripped the wheel so hard I thought my knuckles would pop, pulled on it with everything I had.

45451.base_text: Then I tried turning it the other direction, and the wheel spun.

variants.text: Then I tried turning it the other direction, and the wheel spun.

45451.base_text: I yanked it around, then forced myself up against the hatch, lungs burning, kicking hard, and pushed and swung it up and open, and then I was through, breaking the surface. I breathed, huge and deep.

variants.text: I yanked it around, then forced myself up against the hatch, lungs burning, kicking hard, and pushed and swung it up and open, and then I was through, breaking the surface. I breathed, huge and deep.

45451.base_text: Then I coughed. Clutching the sides of the hatch, I coughed, blinked, tried to take stock of this new hexagonal room. A huge crack had opened in the floor, and all the water had drained out. The groaning and clanging was sharper up here, out of the water, but mostly coming from beneath.

45451.base_text: I pulled myself out of the raised pillar and tumbled to the bucking ground, wiped blood from my face. I was gasping, coughing, bleeding, hurting, panicking, and also, somehow, living. Deservedly or not.

variants.text: I pulled myself out of the raised pillar and tumbled to the bucking ground, wiped blood from my face. I was gasping, coughing, bleeding, hurting, panicking, and also, somehow, living. Deservedly or not.

45451.base_text: Piled on the lip of one of the tunnels out were a pair of shoes and a dry, folded t-shirt.

variants.text: Piled on the lip of one of the tunnels out were a pair of shoes and a dry, folded t-shirt.

45451.base_text: An ear-splitting crack rang off the walls. Bricks fell from the ceiling in a deadly shower, landing a dozen feet away. I grabbed the shirt and pulled it on over my wet torso, slipped the shoes over numb and wrinkled feet. The ground heaved beneath me like the back of a whale taking a colossal breath before diving deep, and as it did it swallowed up the bricks, incorporated them neatly into itself like a child’s plastic puzzle pieces falling into matching slots.

45451.base_text: The floor of the bathroom, through the open hatch, was gone. Tile walls descended, vanishing into darkness. They were splitting and rejoining, like some fractal screensaver, an optical illusion in constant motion from the corner of your eye but damnably still if you looked right at it.

45451.base_text: Something was broken. Something had diverged too far. There were too many possibilities and they couldn’t all fit. They needed more room.

variants.text: Something was broken. Something had diverged too far. There were too many possibilities and they couldn’t all fit. They needed more room.

45451.base_text: Time, I decided, to get the hell out.

variants.text: Time, I decided, to get the hell out.

45451.base_text: With a great belching snap, the floor punctured upwards and a spout of cloudy water billowed up. Another spout exploded from the other side of the room. I picked one of the circular tunnels and started running down it, as fast as I could on my hobbled leg, while behind me the depths of Downstairs sloughed and squirmed into new permutations, unseen. I was too busy living to look back.

Chromium sink fixtures and a frosted-glass shower threw back cerulean light. In contrast to the other flooded chambers there was no mold, no algae, no water damage. It might have been flooded seconds before.

45452.base_text: I focused on my strokes, old swimming lessons coming back. This was a different sort of lane, of course: the floor brown carpet, plaster-of-paris above instead of a shimmering boundary of air. And the wounded leg slowed me down: it hurt, every time I kicked. But I wasn’t worried, not yet. I had good lungs. I could swim for a while.

45452.base_text: Through the door was what looked like a small porch or mud room. Boots and shoes tumbled weightless in the water. The rope stopped here, tied to a capped metal pipe. The opposite wall was a sliding glass patio door.

45452.base_text: The airlock.

Through the glass it was dark. All I could see was my own blue reflection holding the glowstick. Seeing myself floating there, a hit of adrenaline coursed through me. How much air was left in my lungs? More than half what I’d started with? Doubt flooded into me. This is crazy. I can’t do this. I forced the thought from my mind, replaced it with: Just hurry. Hurry and get it over with.

45452.base_text: Another me.

Everything changed. The water cooled; the pressure and ambient sound in my ears shifted. I could see the vague outlines of another sliding door just ahead of me, but it seemed too as if I floated in a cavernous space, a space beyond measuring, the other door impossibly distant. Disoriented, I turned around to shut the one I’d come through—remembering they couldn’t both be open at once—and as I did another shock of change swept through me, crystallizing into something immense, yawning, terrorful. 45452.base_text: The water cooled; the pressure and ambient sound in my ears shifted. I could see the vague outlines of another sliding door just ahead of me, but it seemed too as if I floated in a cavernous space, a space beyond measuring, the other door impossibly distant. Disoriented, I turned around to shut the one I’d come through—remembering they couldn’t both be open at once—and as I did another shock of change swept through me, crystallizing into something immense, yawning, terrorful. I remembered the spring Elder Niko had spoken of

45452.base_text: The water trembled and around us foundations groaned, but I reached down and grabbed Niko’s hand and held it tight against the wriggling water, and he gripped it back. We stared across the gap at my double, defiant. I realized half the sick anxiety I’d been feeling was from my growing proximity to him, subsumed by the general terror of what we were doing. But that wasn’t why I gripped Niko’s hand so tight.

45452.base_text: We were breaking the rules of this place. Staring asynchrony in the face. And we weren’t backing down.

variants.text: We were breaking the rules of this place. Staring asynchrony in the face. And we weren’t backing down.

45452.base_text: We were going through anyway.
The rumbling petered out, died away. Shoes disturbed by the shaking drifted around us, their long laces waving like antennae.

45452.base_text: EXPANDING ONCE AGAIN

Slowed by dream-syrup, fighting awed stupor from these whispers of immensity, I turned my back on that powerful water at the center, pulled the glass door shut, staring numb as it slid implacable down its track.

45452.base_text: All this had taken only seconds. I knew every one mattered. Across the gap I saw the other Ryan reach for his sliding glass door, and found myself doing the same, unsure which of us had moved first.

45452.base_text: pools as clear as air
this stream
In the last second before the door clicked shut and my glowstick guttered out, I saw something reflected in the glass. There were people floating behind me.

45452.base_text: In lockstep, our doors slid open, and we swam forward into the black water between, me tugging Niko behind. As we reached the portal the floor and ceiling dropped away. Everything was dark.

45452.base_text: deep at the roots of this place: a spring that split and split and split again, endless. I felt possibilities branching in the water around me, but even more in the waters inside me, in the part of me inside the waters. Branching, expanding, growing like mold in a petri dish but spilling out of the dish now, spreading through the lab into the walls, the world

45452.base_text: SUCH WONDERS

They drifted in that immense and empty space, lit a gangrenous blue by the light of my glowstick. Three of them. All with my body, my clothes. My face. Their wide-open eyes (my eyes) were fixed on me as they floated gently forward, converging.

45452.base_text: and it was as if I was the mold, the spring, an effervescent source spilling out into infinite variation, branches branching and branched again into an unfillable space, filling it. Boundless, multiplied. Multiplicious.

45452.base_text: I screamed, bubbles of precious oxygen exploding from my mouth. I yanked the handle of the door, but it wouldn’t budge. I clawed at it, slammed my fist against the glass. The darkness was absolute, thickened by the potent water into a solid, crushing thing. The door wouldn’t open and they were right behind me they were coming they were going to get me and I twisted wildly, pressed hands to the glass behind me, trying to guess their position, but it was hopeless. I couldn’t see. I’d squandered my air. Hands would close around my neck, my face, and I’d scream again one last time and drown, thrashing in pain and terror and darkness. Alone.

45452.base_text: No.

Anger pierced through fear. Maybe I had issues and maybe I’d made mistakes, and maybe I even deserved this, to be strangled by my own soulless doppelgangers in a shitty basement apartment with delusions of grandeur. But I didn’t want to die, and being alone had nothing to do with it. I wasn’t going to let this happen to me just because my first love had betrayed me and I couldn’t forgive him, just because my second was trapped in another universe and I could never, ever see him again. None of that mattered. I was still here. I was still alive.

Think.

45452.base_text: And as we turned around to swim across that heady gap, facing each other again, we both raised our glowsticks high. And then we saw them.

45452.base_text: Gripping my panic by the neck before it ran wild, snarling like a cornered animal, I put my feet against the glass door behind me and pushed off hard, as hard as I could.

The pain in my wounded calf went white-hot but I barely noticed it. I shot straight forward, intent, threading the gap like a needle, right through the center of the things closing in.

45452.base_text: The other Ryan had failed to open his door, too, but as he’d turned around a coincidence had pried apart our synchronicity even further. There were more of the floating Ryan-things on his side—an accident of distribution maybe—and the few seconds Niko and I had to act had already run out for him. As he bent his legs to push off from the glass door, they reached him.

45452.base_text: Seeing stars, tasting blood, I scrabbled for the handle, but I couldn’t find it. My hands slid off smooth glass in every direction. I smeared them across it frantically, up, down, side to side, kicking out with my feet, conscious every second of those things behind me, turning, drifting back towards me, closing in; of the air in my lungs, running low. Running out.

45452.base_text: He screamed, eyes going wide as their fingers wrapped around his hair, caressed his arms, reached pale white fingers into his mouth. Bubbles of air exploded from it as he twisted frantically, trying to shake them off. Hands closed around his neck, twisted his arms, pulled his head back by his hair to a terrible angle; hands that seemed unsure if they meant to caress or kill. He was panicking, writhing in the water like a trapped eel, dying.

My air was almost gone. I’d lost some panicking, and my muscles burned through the rest as I shot myself through the airlock. An urge to breathe was taking hold of me, a tingling thrum running through my body as cells clamored for air. My lungs were empty. I couldn’t swim again the distance I’d come, either forward or back.

45452.base_text: It’s a horrible thing to watch yourself drown. My brain disconnected, floated away, observed only in abstractions as the me across the gap spasmed and convulsed, surrounded by things that shared our face, pressing forward, closer, eager, like they wanted to feed off the flicker of his death. The guttering green of his thrashing glowstick was doubled, reflecting mirrored patterns in the glass behind him.

45452.base_text: More of the Ryan-things were drifting toward us, Niko was yanking frantic at my arm, but I couldn’t move, couldn’t react, struggling to grasp that fleeting thought like a half-remembered dream. Neurons tried to spark. The doubled reflection. Something had almost slipped into place. Like a puzzle in that damn adventure game, a puzzle you don’t even know if there’s an answer to until the moment you see it.

This wasn’t one of the things, I realized. It was me. My double, from the other side.

45452.base_text: We stared at each other and both realized I wasn’t going to make it.

45452.base_text: In the glass, there were no swarming figures. They weren’t real.

45452.base_text: Blood diffused from my nose in billowing red clouds; the cut on my leg burned a deep, dangerous ache. My torn fingernails stung where I’d clawed at the door. I was damaged, flawed. The worse-off copy. Looking at him, unharmed, whole, I accepted that I was about to die. It was surprisingly easy.

45452.base_text: There was no way, no time to explain this to Niko. So I wrapped my arms around him tight, felt for the glass door with my legs, shut my eyes, and pushed off hard towards the swarm of encroaching Orions, as hard as I could.

45452.base_text: Something brushed my leg. I kicked forward with all the strength I had. Two fingertips bounced off my forehead, trailed through my hair, but we were moving too fast for them, we were through, we were past them. I’d done it.

His face winced at this in exact sympathy with mine, but he didn’t pull up, slow down. Instead he crashed right into me, hard. Tumbling, he wrapped his arms around me, held me, did the last thing I’d have ever expected.

But as I did I realized the reason for his panic was far more serious.

He pushed his mouth to mine, and flooded my lungs with his air.

45452.base_text: He was out of air.

The wrongness had reached an unbearable threshold. But as his lips touched mine the sensation exploded outward, like magnets pushed against repelling poles till they slip from your fingers, flip around, snap into place. The water quivered around us; the room groaned, launching wet clouds of mud from splintering lintels, sending subsonic shockwaves shuddering through us. His breath flowed into me. I couldn’t think, let alone protest or react. Boots tumbled around us, long laces waving like antennae. I remember that.

45452.base_text: Whether he’d lost the last of it screaming, whether his smoker’s lungs were just inferior to mine: it didn’t matter. I could tell at a glance he wouldn’t make it to the other side. He wouldn’t even make it through the door. His face was filled up with crushing desperation, a look that counted seconds until the overwhelming urge to breathe took hold of him. They were almost gone. His lungs were empty.

45452.base_text: And then he was empty, and I was full.

45452.base_text: So I pressed my mouth to his and filled them up. I gave him the last of my breath.

45452.base_text: He pulled back, blinked, smiled a smile I knew from the mirror. It meant Oh, well, what you gonna do.

45452.base_text: His eyes went wide as he realized what I did, and I could feel him fight to pull back, to stop me. But I held him tight, and anyway I knew he couldn’t stop the desperate need of his lungs to expand, to survive, no matter what his forebrain thought it wanted.

45452.base_text: He’d picked me.
In moments, it was done. I was empty, and he was full.

45452.base_text: A huge rumbling crack broke over the growing crescendo of rumbles and groans, and we both looked up. The ceiling had split in a long ugly scar. But the room wasn’t collapsing on us. The split filled in almost immediately with new plaster, just as a different split bisected it, which also instantly filled.

45452.base_text: He would live. He would be the one who made it.

variants.text: He would live. He would be the one who made it.

45452.base_text: The room was getting bigger.

I pulled back, and as I did the water exploded around us like it had come to life, gone in a snap from still to carbonated. All around us the architecture groaned, flexed, heaved, like it too had come alive.

45452.base_text: My double grabbed my elbow, pushed me toward the hall he’d come in through, the way to the hatch to the other world, my world. And I started to swim. I shouldn’t have. I should have thanked him. I should have given back half his air, or dragged him after me, found some way to save him. I should have died. But I didn’t. I swam. I swam with everything I had left.

45452.base_text: Across the gap of thrumming water behind us I saw the glass door we’d come through pull back. Its dimensions and the reflection of my glowstick grew smaller.

variants.text: Across the gap of thrumming water behind us I saw the glass door we’d come through pull back. Its dimensions and the reflection of my glowstick grew smaller.

45452.base_text: He’d made a mistake. Bet on the wrong horse. But I wouldn’t forget it. I wouldn’t forget him.

variants.text: He’d made a mistake. Bet on the wrong horse. But I wouldn’t forget it. I wouldn’t forget him.

45452.base_text: The wall was pulling away.

All around me the architecture was groaning, flexing, like something waking up. Plaster dust pillowed into the flooded hall in thick weightless clouds as the walls split and reformed, split and reformed, like bones breaking and healing and rebreaking, growing fractionally longer each time. I swam past a crack that didn’t fill in but puckered into a new doorway, a flap of wallpaper lengthening and hardening into door. New doorways were spawning all around me; new pits gaped open in the floor. I ignored it all. I swam. I swam for my fucking life.

45452.base_text: Desperate, my own need to breathe becoming overwhelming, I faced forward again and tugged the glass door beside us open; but even as I did, Downstairs expanded. Plaster dust pillowed into the flooded hall in thick weightless clouds as the walls split and reformed, split and reformed, like bones breaking and healing and rebreaking, growing fractionally longer each time. New glass doors spawned above us, below us, to every side. I ignored it all. I pulled the door open along its rail and grabbed Niko’s arm to shove him through.

45452.base_text: The guide rope, taut as a bowstring, snapped, whipping past my face as its two endpoints pulled away from each other. It didn’t matter. I knew the way.

variants.text: The guide rope, taut as a bowstring, snapped, whipping past my face as its two endpoints pulled away from each other. It didn’t matter. I knew the way.

45452.base_text: He gripped the edge as I did, twisting around to grasp my shoulder. There were no words for the look on his face, or for all the things we’d never said to each other and now never would. There was no time to say them and no air to say them with. I could guess what some of them would have been, maybe, but not others. There was so much of him I’d never really seen, never understood, too caught up in manufacturing other versions of him in my head to know the only one who’d really been there. Now I’d never know how much I’d missed.

I swam up to the ceiling—already much higher than a bathroom ceiling should be—put my hands on the wheel of the hatch, and turned.

45452.base_text: I pulled back gently from his grasping hand, and smiled, and tried to put everything left I wanted to say into that.

variants.text: I pulled back gently from his grasping hand, and smiled, and tried to put everything left I wanted to say into that.

45452.base_text: It didn’t budge.

Water frothed around us, twisting, expanding. And then in a flash it began to move. A current tore him from me, limbs flailing, pulling him backward through the mudroom and down the twin of the hall we’d swum through to get here, toward the other hatch. I hoped. Toward the right surface. Even if I’d wanted to follow, I couldn’t have: another current of shockingly cold water had wrapped itself around me like a tendril. An angry, biotic undertow pulled me down, straight down, with vicious force. The reflection of my glowstick strobed as the current pulled me past door after door of sliding glass, faster and faster: a flicker, then a dull throb, fading and mingling with the phantom patterns and flashes of color now dancing across my vision as my oxygen-starved brain began to shut down.

45452.base_text: The groaning rumbles of hell surrounded me, my body was once again starting to tingle as my second lungful of air reached its end, my face throbbed and my leg was on fire, and the wheel wouldn’t turn.

45452.base_text: In a moment I’d breathe in, and I wondered what it would be like to inhale those waters of possibility, let that multiplying spring inside me. Let it fill me up. I harbored no illusions, of course: I’d seen it happen to the other Ryan. I’d die. But a beautiful way to go, in the abstract at least. A life spent worrying about possibilities would end by drowning in them. Neat.

45452.base_text: This peaceful thought had so taken me I was caught utterly by surprise when the current shifted and smashed me into a pane of glass with so much force it shattered. Rocketing through a waterlogged hall of turbulent water, surrounded by tumbling fragments of glass, head throbbing and vision expiring, I opened my mouth in shock and, before I could remember I was waiting for a poetic moment to die, breathed in.

45452.base_text: I yanked it around, then forced myself up against the hatch, lungs burning, kicking hard, and pushed and swung it up and open, and then I was through, breaking the surface. I breathed, huge and deep.

45452.base_text: Then I coughed. Clutching the sides of the hatch, I coughed, blinked, tried to take stock of this new hexagonal room. A huge crack had opened in the floor, and all the water had drained out. The groaning and clanging was sharper up here, out of the water, but mostly coming from beneath.

45452.base_text: I pulled myself out of the raised pillar and tumbled to the bucking ground, wiped blood from my face. I was gasping, coughing, bleeding, hurting, panicking, and also, somehow, living. Deservedly or not.

45452.base_text: Piled on the lip of one of the tunnels out were a pair of shoes and a dry, folded t-shirt.

45452.base_text: An ear-splitting crack rang off the walls. Bricks fell from the ceiling in a deadly shower, landing a dozen feet away. I grabbed the shirt and pulled it on over my wet torso, slipped the shoes over numb and wrinkled feet. The ground heaved beneath me like the back of a whale taking a colossal breath before diving deep, and as it did it swallowed up the bricks, incorporated them neatly into itself like a child’s plastic puzzle pieces falling into matching slots.

They were splitting and rejoining, like some fractal screensaver, an optical illusion in constant motion from the corner of your eye but damnably still if you looked right at it.

45452.base_text: Something was broken. Something had diverged too far. There were too many possibilities and they couldn’t all fit. They needed more room.

45452.base_text: Time, I decided, to get the hell out.

variants.text: Time, I decided, to get the hell out.

45452.base_text: With a great belching snap, the floor punctured upwards and a spout of cloudy water billowed up. Another spout exploded from the other side of the room. I picked one of the circular tunnels and started running down it, as fast as I could on my hobbled leg, while behind me the depths of Downstairs sloughed and squirmed into new permutations, unseen. I was too busy living to look back.

Chromium sink fixtures and a frosted-glass shower threw back cerulean light. In contrast to the other flooded chambers there was no mold, no algae, no water damage. It might have been flooded seconds before.

45453.base_text: I focused on my strokes, old swimming lessons coming back. This was a different sort of lane, of course: the floor brown carpet, plaster-of-paris above instead of a shimmering boundary of air. And the wounded leg slowed me down: it hurt, every time I kicked. But I wasn’t worried, not yet. I had good lungs. I could swim for a while.

45453.base_text: The rope turned a corner into a large unfurnished room with a half-dozen washers and dryers piled in a corner. I swam past them, mechanical, calm, following the rope through an open doorway opposite.

45453.base_text: Through the door was what looked like a small porch or mud room. Boots and shoes tumbled weightless in the water. The rope stopped here, tied to a capped metal pipe. The opposite wall was a sliding glass patio door.

45453.base_text: The airlock.

Through the glass it was dark. All I could see was my own blue reflection holding the glowstick. Seeing myself floating there, a hit of adrenaline coursed through me. How much air was left in my lungs? More than half what I’d started with? Doubt flooded into me. This is crazy. I can’t do this. I forced the thought from my mind, replaced it with: Just hurry. Hurry and get it over with.

45453.base_text: Another me.

Everything changed. The water cooled; the pressure and ambient sound in my ears shifted. I could see the vague outlines of another sliding door just ahead of me, but it seemed too as if I floated in a cavernous space, a space beyond measuring, the other door impossibly distant. Disoriented, I turned around to shut the one I’d come through—remembering they couldn’t both be open at once—and as I did another shock of change swept through me, crystallizing into something immense, yawning, terrorful. I remembered the spring Elder Niko had spoken of

45453.base_text: The water trembled and around us foundations groaned, but I reached down and grabbed Niko’s hand and held it tight against the wriggling water, and he gripped it back. We stared across the gap at my double, defiant. I realized half the sick anxiety I’d been feeling was from my growing proximity to him, subsumed by the general terror of what we were doing. But that wasn’t why I gripped Niko’s hand so tight.

45453.base_text: EXPANDING ONCE AGAIN

Slowed by dream-syrup, fighting awed stupor from these whispers of immensity, I turned my back on that powerful water at the center, pulled the glass door shut, staring numb as it slid implacable down its track.

45453.base_text: All this had taken only seconds. I knew every one mattered. Across the gap I saw the other Ryan reach for his sliding glass door, and found myself doing the same, unsure which of us had moved first.

45453.base_text: SUCH WONDERS

They drifted in that immense and empty space, lit a gangrenous blue by the light of my glowstick. Three of them. All with my body, my clothes. My face. Their wide-open eyes (my eyes) were fixed on me as they floated gently forward, converging.

45453.base_text: I screamed, bubbles of precious oxygen exploding from my mouth. I yanked the handle of the door, but it wouldn’t budge. I clawed at it, slammed my fist against the glass. The darkness was absolute, thickened by the potent water into a solid, crushing thing. The door wouldn’t open and they were right behind me they were coming they were going to get me and I twisted wildly, pressed hands to the glass behind me, trying to guess their position, but it was hopeless. I couldn’t see. I’d squandered my air. Hands would close around my neck, my face, and I’d scream again one last time and drown, thrashing in pain and terror and darkness. Alone.

45453.base_text: No.

Anger pierced through fear. Maybe I had issues and maybe I’d made mistakes, and maybe I even deserved this, to be strangled by my own soulless doppelgangers in a shitty basement apartment with delusions of grandeur. But I didn’t want to die, and being alone had nothing to do with it. I wasn’t going to let this happen to me just because my first love had betrayed me and I couldn’t forgive him, just because my second was trapped in another universe and I could never, ever see him again. None of that mattered. I was still here. I was still alive.

45453.base_text: Gripping my panic by the neck before it ran wild, snarling like a cornered animal, I put my feet against the glass door behind me and pushed off hard, as hard as I could.

45453.base_text: Dozens. Floating, unbreathing. Eyes open.
The pain in my wounded calf went white-hot but I barely noticed it. I shot straight forward, intent, threading the gap like a needle, right through the center of the things closing in.

variants.text: The pain in my wounded calf went white-hot but I barely noticed it. I shot straight forward, intent, threading the gap like a needle, right through the center of the things closing in.

45453.base_text: Watching.
I hoped.
I screamed, bubbles of precious oxygen exploding from my mouth, and then they came for us.

variants.text: I screamed, bubbles of precious oxygen exploding from my mouth, and then they came for us.

45453.base_text: Something brushed my leg. I kicked forward, pulled water with cupped hands and all the strength I had. Two fingertips bounced off my forehead, trailed through my hair, but I was moving too fast for them, I was through, I was past them. I’d done it.

45453.base_text: I twisted around and yanked the handle of the door, but it wouldn’t budge. I clawed at it, slammed my fist against the glass. The door wouldn’t open and they were right behind they were coming they were going to get us and I twisted wildly, pressed hands to the glass behind me, but it was hopeless. There were too many of them, drifting forward with hands outstretched, serene expressions on their faces. Beside me, Niko was preparing to push off against the glass and make a break for the other side, but faltered as he saw what was happening across from us.

45453.base_text: I surged forward, swimming hard, a savage rictus of victory splitting my face, and then with a crunch and flash of pain I slammed face-first into something hard and smooth. Glass. The door on the opposite side.

variants.text: I surged forward, swimming hard, a savage rictus of victory splitting my face, and then with a crunch and flash of pain I slammed face-first into something hard and smooth. Glass. The door on the opposite side.

45453.base_text: The other Ryan had failed to open his door, too, but as he’d turned around a coincidence had pried apart our synchronicity even further. There were more of the floating Ryan-things on his side—an accident of distribution maybe—and the few seconds Niko and I had to act had already run out for him. As he bent his legs to push off from the glass door, they reached him.

45453.base_text: Seeing stars, tasting blood, I scrabbled for the handle, but I couldn’t find it. My hands slid off smooth glass in every direction. I smeared them across it frantically, up, down, side to side, kicking out with my feet, conscious every second of those things behind me, turning, drifting back towards me, closing in; of the air in my lungs, running low. Running out.

45453.base_text: He screamed, eyes going wide as their fingers wrapped around his hair, caressed his arms, reached pale white fingers into his mouth. Bubbles of air exploded from it as he twisted frantically, trying to shake them off. Hands closed around his neck, twisted his arms, pulled his head back by his hair to a terrible angle; hands that seemed unsure if they meant to caress or kill. He was panicking, writhing in the water like a trapped eel, dying.

45453.base_text: There: the handle. I pulled it sideways, and as the door slid open in its groove my glowstick came back on, the most glorious shade of blue you could possibly imagine.

45453.base_text: Before we could move or even start swimming forward to help him, his body spasmed as he breathed in.

45453.base_text: I kicked forward into the other anteroom and pulled the door shut behind me, not looking back. There was no sign of the things, the Shapes, the echoes, whatever they were. I’d escaped them. My face throbbed with a sharp, spreading pain. But I had a bigger problem. In fact with lightheaded desperation I realized I was in deep, deep shit.

My air was almost gone. I’d lost some panicking, and my muscles burned through the rest as I shot myself through the airlock. An urge to breathe was taking hold of me, a tingling thrum running through my body as cells clamored for air. My lungs were empty. I couldn’t swim again the distance I’d come, either forward or back.

45453.base_text: It’s a horrible thing to watch yourself drown. My brain disconnected, floated away, observed only in abstractions as the me across the gap spasmed and convulsed, surrounded by things that shared our face, pressing forward, closer, eager, like they wanted to feed off the flicker of his death. The guttering green of his thrashing glowstick was doubled, reflecting mirrored patterns in the glass behind him.

45453.base_text: I watched myself swim into the room, holding it.

45453.base_text: More of the Ryan-things were drifting toward us, Niko was yanking frantic at my arm, but I couldn’t move, couldn’t react, struggling to grasp that fleeting thought like a half-remembered dream. Neurons tried to spark. The doubled reflection. Something had almost slipped into place. Like a puzzle in that damn adventure game, a puzzle you don’t even know if there’s an answer to until the moment you see it.

This wasn’t one of the things, I realized. It was me. My double, from the other side.

45453.base_text: Blood diffused from my nose in billowing red clouds; the cut on my leg burned a deep, dangerous ache. My torn fingernails stung where I’d clawed at the door. I was damaged, flawed. The worse-off copy. Looking at him, unharmed, whole, I accepted that I was about to die. It was surprisingly easy.

He tilted his head, studying me. As if considering something. Or trying to see me, really see me, like I’d tried so many times to see Niko.

45453.base_text: There was no way, no time to explain this to Niko. So I wrapped my arms around him tight, felt for the glass door with my legs, shut my eyes, and pushed off hard towards the swarm of encroaching Orions, as hard as I could.

45453.base_text: And then he launched himself at me. At once the sense of wrongness spiked, as if approaching some exponential maxima. His face winced at this in exact sympathy with mine, but he didn’t pull up, slow down. Instead he crashed right into me, hard. Tumbling, he wrapped his arms around me, held me, did the last thing I’d have ever expected.

45453.base_text: We’d reached the glass door on the other side; below us, the drowned Orion sank into erasing darkness, no longer struggling. I couldn’t help him. But Niko was kicking and thrashing in what I’d assumed was terror at the illusory Mockups. To pull the door open I’d have to let him go. But as I did I realized the reason for his panic was far more serious.

45453.base_text: He was out of air.

The wrongness had reached an unbearable threshold. But as his lips touched mine the sensation exploded outward, like magnets pushed against repelling poles till they slip from your fingers, flip around, snap into place. The water quivered around us; the room groaned, launching wet clouds of mud from splintering lintels, sending subsonic shockwaves shuddering through us. His breath flowed into me. I couldn’t think, let alone protest or react. Boots tumbled around us, long laces waving like antennae. I remember that.

45453.base_text: Whether he’d lost the last of it screaming, whether his smoker’s lungs were just inferior to mine: it didn’t matter. I could tell at a glance he wouldn’t make it to the other side. He wouldn’t even make it through the door. His face was filled up with crushing desperation, a look that counted seconds until the overwhelming urge to breathe took hold of him. They were almost gone. His lungs were empty.

variants.text: In moments, it was done. I was empty, and he was full.

45453.base_text: A huge rumbling crack broke over the growing crescendo of rumbles and groans, and we both looked up. The ceiling had split in a long ugly scar. But the room wasn’t collapsing on us. The split filled in almost immediately with new plaster, just as a different split bisected it, which also instantly filled.

The split filled in almost immediately with new plaster, just as a different split bisected it, which also instantly filled.

45453.base_text: He would live. He would be the one who made it.

variants.text: He would live. He would be the one who made it.

45453.base_text: The room was getting bigger.

I pulled back, and as I did the water exploded around us like it had come to life, gone in a snap from still to carbonated. All around us the architecture groaned, flexed, heaved, like it too had come alive.

variants.text: I pulled back, and as I did the water exploded around us like it had come to life, gone in a snap from still to carbonated. All around us the architecture groaned, flexed, heaved, like it too had come alive.

45453.base_text: My double grabbed my elbow, pushed me toward the hall he’d come in through, the way to the hatch to the other world, my world. And I started to swim. I shouldn’t have. I should have thanked him. I should have given back half his air, or dragged him after me, found some way to save him. I should have died. But I didn’t. I swam. I swam with everything I had left.

45453.base_text: Across the gap of thrumming water behind us I saw the glass door we’d come through pull back. Its dimensions and the reflection of my glowstick grew smaller.

variants.text: Across the gap of thrumming water behind us I saw the glass door we’d come through pull back. Its dimensions and the reflection of my glowstick grew smaller.

45453.base_text: He’d made a mistake. Bet on the wrong horse. But I wouldn’t forget it. I wouldn’t forget him.

variants.text: He’d made a mistake. Bet on the wrong horse. But I wouldn’t forget it. I wouldn’t forget him.

45453.base_text: The wall was pulling away.

All around me the architecture was groaning, flexing, like something waking up. Plaster dust pillowed into the flooded hall in thick weightless clouds as the walls split and reformed, split and reformed, like bones breaking and healing and rebreaking, growing fractionally longer each time. I swam past a crack that didn’t fill in but puckered into a new doorway, a flap of wallpaper lengthening and hardening into door. New doorways were spawning all around me; new pits gaped open in the floor. I ignored it all. I swam. I swam for my fucking life.

New doorways were spawning all around me; new pits gaped open in the floor. I ignored it all. I swam. I swam for my fucking life.

45453.base_text: Desperate, my own need to breathe becoming overwhelming, I faced forward again and tugged the glass door beside us open; but even as I did, Downstairs expanded. Plaster dust pillowed into the flooded hall in thick weightless clouds as the walls split and reformed, split and reformed, like bones breaking and healing and rebreaking, growing fractionally longer each time. New glass doors spawned above us, below us, to every side. I ignored it all. I pulled the door open along its rail and grabbed Niko’s arm to shove him through.

New glass doors spawned above us, below us, to every side. I ignored it all. I pulled the door open along its rail and grabbed Niko’s arm to shove him through.

45453.base_text: The guide rope, taut as a bowstring, snapped, whipping past my face as its two endpoints pulled away from each other. It didn’t matter. I knew the way.

variants.text: The guide rope, taut as a bowstring, snapped, whipping past my face as its two endpoints pulled away from each other. It didn’t matter. I knew the way.

45453.base_text: He gripped the edge as I did, twisting around to grasp my shoulder. There were no words for the look on his face, or for all the things we’d never said to each other and now never would. There was no time to say them and no air to say them with. I could guess what some of them would have been, maybe, but not others. There was so much of him I’d never really seen, never understood, too caught up in manufacturing other versions of him in my head to know the only one who’d really been there. Now I’d never know how much I’d missed.

45453.base_text: I swam into the mirror bathroom, shiny new sinks sprouting on the floor, on the ceiling; the toilet multiplying and splitting in porcelain osmosis, someone’s pretentious art project. I swam up to the ceiling—already much higher than a bathroom ceiling should be—put my hands on the wheel of the hatch, and turned.

45453.base_text: I pulled back gently from his grasping hand, and smiled, and tried to put everything left I wanted to say into that.

variants.text: I pulled back gently from his grasping hand, and smiled, and tried to put everything left I wanted to say into that.

45453.base_text: It didn’t budge.

Water frothed around us, twisting, expanding. And then in a flash it began to move. A current tore him from me, limbs flailing, pulling him backward through the mudroom and down the twin of the hall we’d swum through to get here, toward the other hatch. I hoped. Toward the right surface. Even if I’d wanted to follow, I couldn’t have: another current of shockingly cold water had wrapped itself around me like a tendril. An angry, biotic undertow pulled me down, straight down, with vicious force. The reflection of my glowstick strobed as the current pulled me past door after door of sliding glass, faster and faster: a flicker, then a dull throb, fading and mingling with the phantom patterns and flashes of color now dancing across my vision as my oxygen-starved brain began to shut down.

45453.base_text: The groaning rumbles of hell surrounded me, my body was once again starting to tingle as my second lungful of air reached its end, my face throbbed and my leg was on fire, and the wheel wouldn’t turn.

variants.text: The groaning rumbles of hell surrounded me, my body was once again starting to tingle as my second lungful of air reached its end, my face throbbed and my leg was on fire, and the wheel wouldn’t turn.

45453.base_text: In a moment I’d breathe in, and I wondered what it would be like to inhale those waters of possibility, let that multiplying spring inside me. Let it fill me up. I harbored no illusions, of course: I’d seen it happen to the other Ryan. I’d die. But a beautiful way to go, in the abstract at least. A life spent worrying about possibilities would end by drowning in them. Neat.

45453.base_text: I pounded on the hatch, screaming in fury, the sound utterly lost in the cacophonous eruption of architecture beneath me.

variants.text: I pounded on the hatch, screaming in fury, the sound utterly lost in the cacophonous eruption of architecture beneath me.

45453.base_text: This peaceful thought had so taken me I was caught utterly by surprise when the current shifted and smashed me into a pane of glass with so much force it shattered. Rocketing through a waterlogged hall of turbulent water, surrounded by tumbling fragments of glass, head throbbing and vision expiring, I opened my mouth in shock and, before I could remember I was waiting for a poetic moment to die, breathed in.

45453.base_text: I braced myself, gripped the wheel so hard I thought my knuckles would pop, pulled on it with everything I had.

variants.text: I braced myself, gripped the wheel so hard I thought my knuckles would pop, pulled on it with everything I had.

45453.base_text: Then I tried turning it the other direction, and the wheel spun.

variants.text: Then I tried turning it the other direction, and the wheel spun.

45453.base_text: I yanked it around, then forced myself up against the hatch, lungs burning, kicking hard, and pushed and swung it up and open, and then I was through, breaking the surface. I breathed, huge and deep.

variants.text: I yanked it around, then forced myself up against the hatch, lungs burning, kicking hard, and pushed and swung it up and open, and then I was through, breaking the surface. I breathed, huge and deep.

45453.base_text: Then I coughed. Clutching the sides of the hatch, I coughed, blinked, tried to take stock of this new hexagonal room. A huge crack had opened in the floor, and all the water had drained out. The groaning and clanging was sharper up here, out of the water, but mostly coming from beneath.

45453.base_text: I pulled myself out of the raised pillar and tumbled to the bucking ground, wiped blood from my face. I was gasping, coughing, bleeding, hurting, panicking, and also, somehow, living. Deservedly or not.

variants.text: I pulled myself out of the raised pillar and tumbled to the bucking ground, wiped blood from my face. I was gasping, coughing, bleeding, hurting, panicking, and also, somehow, living. Deservedly or not.

45453.base_text: Piled on the lip of one of the tunnels out were a pair of shoes and a dry, folded t-shirt.

variants.text: Piled on the lip of one of the tunnels out were a pair of shoes and a dry, folded t-shirt.

45453.base_text: An ear-splitting crack rang off the walls. Bricks fell from the ceiling in a deadly shower, landing a dozen feet away. I grabbed the shirt and pulled it on over my wet torso, slipped the shoes over numb and wrinkled feet. The ground heaved beneath me like the back of a whale taking a colossal breath before diving deep, and as it did it swallowed up the bricks, incorporated them neatly into itself like a child’s plastic puzzle pieces falling into matching slots.

45453.base_text: The floor of the bathroom, through the open hatch, was gone. Tile walls descended, vanishing into darkness. They were splitting and rejoining, like some fractal screensaver, an optical illusion in constant motion from the corner of your eye but damnably still if you looked right at it.

45453.base_text: Something was broken. Something had diverged too far. There were too many possibilities and they couldn’t all fit. They needed more room.

variants.text: Something was broken. Something had diverged too far. There were too many possibilities and they couldn’t all fit. They needed more room.

45453.base_text: Time, I decided, to get the hell out.

variants.text: Time, I decided, to get the hell out.

45453.base_text: With a great belching snap, the floor punctured upwards and a spout of cloudy water billowed up. Another spout exploded from the other side of the room. I picked one of the circular tunnels and started running down it, as fast as I could on my hobbled leg, while behind me the depths of Downstairs sloughed and squirmed into new permutations, unseen. I was too busy living to look back.

45457.base_text: The flooded bathroom was lined with tile that might have been a pale yellow but glowed blue in the light of my glowstick. Chromium sink fixtures and a frosted-glass shower threw back cerulean light. In contrast to the other flooded chambers there was no mold, no algae, no water damage. It might have been flooded seconds before.

45457.base_text: I focused on my strokes, old swimming lessons coming back. This was a different sort of lane, of course: the floor brown carpet, plaster-of-paris above instead of a shimmering boundary of air. And the wounded leg slowed me down: it hurt, every time I kicked. But I wasn’t worried, not yet. I had good lungs. I could swim for a while.

45457.base_text: Through the door was what looked like a small porch or mud room. Boots and shoes tumbled weightless in the water. The rope stopped here, tied to a capped metal pipe. The opposite wall was a sliding glass patio door.

45457.base_text: The airlock.

Through the glass it was dark. All I could see was my own blue reflection holding the glowstick. Seeing myself floating there, a hit of adrenaline coursed through me. How much air was left in my lungs? More than half what I’d started with? Doubt flooded into me. This is crazy. I can’t do this. I forced the thought from my mind, replaced it with: Just hurry. Hurry and get it over with.

45457.base_text: And as I swam past the threshold something changed.

45457.base_text: Another me.

Everything changed. The water cooled; the pressure and ambient sound in my ears shifted. I could see the vague outlines of another sliding door just ahead of me, but it seemed too as if I floated in a cavernous space, a space beyond measuring, the other door impossibly distant. 45457.base_text: I screamed, bubbles of precious oxygen exploding from my mouth. I yanked the handle of the door, but it wouldn’t budge. I clawed at it, slammed my fist against the glass. The darkness was absolute, thickened by the potent water into a solid, crushing thing. The door wouldn’t open and they were right behind me they were coming they were going to get me and I twisted wildly, pressed hands to the glass behind me, trying to guess their position, but it was hopeless. I couldn’t see. I’d squandered my air. Hands would close around my neck, my face, and I’d scream again one last time and drown, thrashing in pain and terror and darkness. Alone.

45457.base_text: No.

Anger pierced through fear. Maybe I had issues and maybe I’d made mistakes, and maybe I even deserved this, to be strangled by my own soulless doppelgangers in a shitty basement apartment with delusions of grandeur. But I didn’t want to die, and being alone had nothing to do with it. I wasn’t going to let this happen to me just because my first love had betrayed me and I couldn’t forgive him, just because my second was trapped in another universe and I could never, ever see him again. None of that mattered. I was still here. I was still alive.

45457.base_text: It’s a horrible thing to watch yourself drown. My brain disconnected, floated away, observed only in abstractions as the me across the gap spasmed and convulsed, surrounded by things that shared our face, pressing forward, closer, eager, like they wanted to feed off the flicker of his death. The guttering green of his thrashing glowstick was doubled, reflecting mirrored patterns in the glass behind him.

45457.base_text: I watched myself swim into the room, holding it.

variants.text: I watched myself swim into the room, holding it.

45457.base_text: More of the Ryan-things were drifting toward us, Niko was yanking frantic at my arm, but I couldn’t move, couldn’t react, struggling to grasp that fleeting thought like a half-remembered dream. Neurons tried to spark. The doubled reflection. Something had almost slipped into place. Like a puzzle in that damn adventure game, a puzzle you don’t even know if there’s an answer to until the moment you see it.

45457.base_text: Amidst all the panicked horror and desperation, I hadn’t noticed the wrongness creep up on me, but now I realized that sick feeling had been there all along, getting stronger, flavoring my more pressing concerns. This wasn’t one of the things, I realized. It was me. My double, from the other side.

45457.base_text: A glowstick and its reflection, now gone horribly still. But the closer one was occluded by the swarming forms, the shadows that swam around it.

variants.text: A glowstick and its reflection, now gone horribly still. But the closer one was occluded by the swarming forms, the shadows that swam around it.

45457.base_text: We were passing each other, as planned. But the plan had failed.

variants.text: We were passing each other, as planned. But the plan had failed.

45457.base_text: The one in the reflection was clear. In the glass, its light was unobstructed.

variants.text: The one in the reflection was clear. In the glass, its light was unobstructed.

45457.base_text: We stared at each other and both realized I wasn’t going to make it.

variants.text: We stared at each other and both realized I wasn’t going to make it.

45457.base_text: In the glass, there were no swarming figures. They weren’t real.

variants.text: In the glass, there were no swarming figures. They weren’t real.

45457.base_text: Blood diffused from my nose in billowing red clouds; the cut on my leg burned a deep, dangerous ache. My torn fingernails stung where I’d clawed at the door. I was damaged, flawed. The worse-off copy. Looking at him, unharmed, whole, I accepted that I was about to die. It was surprisingly easy.

45457.base_text: They weren’t real.
He tilted his head, studying me. As if considering something. Or trying to see me, really see me, like I’d tried so many times to see Niko.

variants.text: He tilted his head, studying me. As if considering something. Or trying to see me, really see me, like I’d tried so many times to see Niko.

45457.base_text: There was no way, no time to explain this to Niko. So I wrapped my arms around him tight, felt for the glass door with my legs, shut my eyes, and pushed off hard towards the swarm of encroaching Orions, as hard as I could.

45457.base_text: Do it, I thought, I’m too broken to make it. Go back. Or go forward. Just go. Live. Be the one who lives.

variants.text: Do it, I thought, I’m too broken to make it. Go back. Or go forward. Just go. Live. Be the one who lives.

45457.base_text: The pain in my wounded calf went white-hot but I barely noticed it. I shot straight forward, intent, right through the mass of things closing in.

45457.base_text: His expression changed. Just a little.

variants.text: His expression changed. Just a little.

45457.base_text: Something brushed my leg. I kicked forward with all the strength I had. Two fingertips bounced off my forehead, trailed through my hair, but we were moving too fast for them, we were through, we were past them. I’d done it.

45457.base_text: And then he launched himself at me. At once the sense of wrongness spiked, as if approaching some exponential maxima. His face winced at this in exact sympathy with mine, but he didn’t pull up, slow down. Instead he crashed right into me, hard. Tumbling, he wrapped his arms around me, held me, did the last thing I’d have ever expected.

45457.base_text: We’d reached the glass door on the other side; below us, the drowned Orion sank into erasing darkness, no longer struggling. I couldn’t help him. But Niko was kicking and thrashing in what I’d assumed was terror at the illusory Mockups. To pull the door open I’d have to let him go. But as I did I realized the reason for his panic was far more serious.

He pushed his mouth to mine, and flooded my lungs with his air.

45457.base_text: He was out of air.

The wrongness had reached an unbearable threshold. But as his lips touched mine the sensation exploded outward, like magnets pushed against repelling poles till they slip from your fingers, flip around, snap into place. The water quivered around us; the room groaned, launching wet clouds of mud from splintering lintels, sending subsonic shockwaves shuddering through us. His breath flowed into me. I couldn’t think, let alone protest or react. Boots tumbled around us, long laces waving like antennae. I remember that.

45457.base_text: Whether he’d lost the last of it screaming, whether his smoker’s lungs were just inferior to mine: it didn’t matter. I could tell at a glance he wouldn’t make it to the other side. He wouldn’t even make it through the door. His face was filled up with crushing desperation, a look that counted seconds until the overwhelming urge to breathe took hold of him. They were almost gone. His lungs were empty.

45457.base_text: And then he was empty, and I was full.

variants.text: And then he was empty, and I was full.

45457.base_text: So I pressed my mouth to his and filled them up. I gave him the last of my breath.

variants.text: So I pressed my mouth to his and filled them up. I gave him the last of my breath.

45457.base_text: He pulled back, blinked, smiled a smile I knew from the mirror. It meant Oh, well, what you gonna do.

variants.text: He pulled back, blinked, smiled a smile I knew from the mirror. It meant Oh, well, what you gonna do.

45457.base_text: His eyes went wide as he realized what I did, and I could feel him fight to pull back, to stop me. But I held him tight, and anyway I knew he couldn’t stop the desperate need of his lungs to expand, to survive, no matter what his forebrain thought it wanted.

45457.base_text: He’d picked me.
In moments, it was done. I was empty, and he was full.

variants.text: In moments, it was done. I was empty, and he was full.

45457.base_text: A huge rumbling crack broke over the growing crescendo of rumbles and groans, and we both looked up. The ceiling had split in a long ugly scar. But the room wasn’t collapsing on us. The split filled in almost immediately with new plaster, just as a different split bisected it, which also instantly filled.

45457.base_text: He would live. He would be the one who made it.

variants.text: He would live. He would be the one who made it.

45457.base_text: The room was getting bigger.

I pulled back, and as I did the water exploded around us like it had come to life, gone in a snap from still to carbonated. All around us the architecture groaned, flexed, heaved, like it too had come alive.

variants.text: I pulled back, and as I did the water exploded around us like it had come to life, gone in a snap from still to carbonated. All around us the architecture groaned, flexed, heaved, like it too had come alive.

45457.base_text: My double grabbed my elbow, pushed me toward the hall he’d come in through, the way to the hatch to the other world, my world. And I started to swim. I shouldn’t have. I should have thanked him. I should have given back half his air, or dragged him after me, found some way to save him. I should have died. But I didn’t. I swam. I swam with everything I had left.

45457.base_text: Across the gap of thrumming water behind us I saw the glass door we’d come through pull back. Its dimensions and the reflection of my glowstick grew smaller.

variants.text: Across the gap of thrumming water behind us I saw the glass door we’d come through pull back. Its dimensions and the reflection of my glowstick grew smaller.

45457.base_text: He’d made a mistake. Bet on the wrong horse. But I wouldn’t forget it. I wouldn’t forget him.

variants.text: He’d made a mistake. Bet on the wrong horse. But I wouldn’t forget it. I wouldn’t forget him.

45457.base_text: The wall was pulling away.

All around me the architecture was groaning, flexing, like something waking up. Plaster dust pillowed into the flooded hall in thick weightless clouds as the walls split and reformed, split and reformed, like bones breaking and healing and rebreaking, growing fractionally longer each time. I swam past a crack that didn’t fill in but puckered into a new doorway, a flap of wallpaper lengthening and hardening into door. New doorways were spawning all around me; new pits gaped open in the floor. I ignored it all. I swam. I swam for my fucking life.

45457.base_text: Desperate, my own need to breathe becoming overwhelming, I faced forward again and tugged the glass door beside us open; but even as I did, Downstairs expanded. Plaster dust pillowed into the flooded hall in thick weightless clouds as the walls split and reformed, split and reformed, like bones breaking and healing and rebreaking, growing fractionally longer each time. New glass doors spawned above us, below us, to every side. I ignored it all. I pulled the door open along its rail and grabbed Niko’s arm to shove him through.

45457.base_text: The guide rope, taut as a bowstring, snapped, whipping past my face as its two endpoints pulled away from each other. It didn’t matter. I knew the way.

variants.text: The guide rope, taut as a bowstring, snapped, whipping past my face as its two endpoints pulled away from each other. It didn’t matter. I knew the way.

45457.base_text: He gripped the edge as I did, twisting around to grasp my shoulder. There were no words for the look on his face, or for all the things we’d never said to each other and now never would. There was no time to say them and no air to say them with. I could guess what some of them would have been, maybe, but not others. There was so much of him I’d never really seen, never understood, too caught up in manufacturing other versions of him in my head to know the only one who’d really been there. Now I’d never know how much I’d missed.

45457.base_text: I swam into the mirror bathroom, shiny new sinks sprouting on the floor, on the ceiling; the toilet multiplying and splitting in porcelain osmosis, someone’s pretentious art project. I swam up to the ceiling—already much higher than a bathroom ceiling should be—put my hands on the wheel of the hatch, and turned.

45457.base_text: I pulled back gently from his grasping hand, and smiled, and tried to put everything left I wanted to say into that.

variants.text: I pulled back gently from his grasping hand, and smiled, and tried to put everything left I wanted to say into that.

45457.base_text: It didn’t budge.

Water frothed around us, twisting, expanding. And then in a flash it began to move. A current tore him from me, limbs flailing, pulling him backward through the mudroom and down the twin of the hall we’d swum through to get here, toward the other hatch. I hoped. Toward the right surface. Even if I’d wanted to follow, I couldn’t have: another current of shockingly cold water had wrapped itself around me like a tendril. An angry, biotic undertow pulled me down, straight down, with vicious force. The reflection of my glowstick strobed as the current pulled me past door after door of sliding glass, faster and faster: a flicker, then a dull throb, fading and mingling with the phantom patterns and flashes of color now dancing across my vision as my oxygen-starved brain began to shut down.

45457.base_text: The groaning rumbles of hell surrounded me, my body was once again starting to tingle as my second lungful of air reached its end, my face throbbed and my leg was on fire, and the wheel wouldn’t turn.
